headline: Venezuela’s Maduro Captured by U.S. and Flown Out of Country, Trump Says
summary: The U.S. has captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and carried out a “large scale strike” against the country, President Donald Trump said in a social-media post Saturday.  Maduro and his wife have been “flown out of the Country,” Trump said.  The attack follows months of building tension between the U.S. and Venezuela.

content.title: Venezuela’s Maduro Captured by U.S. and Flown Out of Country, Trump Says
content.summary: The U.S. has captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and carried out a “large scale strike” against the country, President Donald Trump said in a social-media post Saturday.  Maduro and his wife have been “flown out of the Country,” Trump said.  The attack follows months of building tension between the U.S. and Venezuela.

headline: Maduro Captured, Indicted After US Airstrikes on Venezuela
summary: President Nicolás Maduro has been charged in the US after he was captured and flown out of Venezuela, following a series of airstrikes that mark an extraordinary escalation in the Trump administration’s months-long campaign against the country.  “The United States of America has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela and its leader, President Nicolas Maduro, who has been, along with his wife, captured and flown out of the Country,” President Donald Trump wrote on social media Saturday.  US Attorney General Pam Bondi said on X Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, have been indicted, with the Venezuelan leader facing charges of “Narco-Terrorism Conspiracy, Cocaine Importation Conspiracy, Possession of Machineguns and Destructive Devices, and Conspiracy to Possess Machineguns and Destructive Devices against the United States.”

content.title: Maduro Captured, Indicted After US Airstrikes on Venezuela
content.summary: President Nicolás Maduro has been charged in the US after he was captured and flown out of Venezuela, following a series of airstrikes that mark an extraordinary escalation in the Trump administration’s months-long campaign against the country.  “The United States of America has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela and its leader, President Nicolas Maduro, who has been, along with his wife, captured and flown out of the Country,” President Donald Trump wrote on social media Saturday.  US Attorney General Pam Bondi said on X Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, have been indicted, with the Venezuelan leader facing charges of “Narco-Terrorism Conspiracy, Cocaine Importation Conspiracy, Possession of Machineguns and Destructive Devices, and Conspiracy to Possess Machineguns and Destructive Devices against the United States.”

headline: Chevron Says Focused on Safety Following U.S. Strike in Venezuela
summary: Chevron, Venezuela's largest foreign investor, said early Saturday that it is focused on the safety of its employees and the integrity of its assets after the U.S. captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife and extracted them from the country.

content.title: Chevron Says Focused on Safety Following U.S. Strike in Venezuela
content.summary: Chevron, Venezuela's largest foreign investor, said early Saturday that it is focused on the safety of its employees and the integrity of its assets after the U.S. captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife and extracted them from the country.

headline: How Maduro's capture affects oil markets will depend on Venezuela's political climate
summary: The impact of Maduro's capture by the US military on global oil prices is likely to depend on how the situation in Venezuela evolves over the next few months.

content.title: How Maduro's capture affects oil markets will depend on Venezuela's political climate
content.summary: The impact of Maduro's capture by the US military on global oil prices is likely to depend on how the situation in Venezuela evolves over the next few months.

headline: What Maduro’s Capture Means for Chevron Stock
summary: The company is the last U.S. oil major still operating in Venezuela, having maintained a continuous presence in the country since the early 20th century.

content.title: What Maduro’s Capture Means for Chevron Stock
content.summary: The company is the last U.S. oil major still operating in Venezuela, having maintained a continuous presence in the country since the early 20th century.

headline: Oil Market May Absorb Maduro Shock Amid Abundant Global Supplies
summary: Venezuela’s oil infrastructure wasn’t affected after a series of US attacks in Caracas and other states, according to people with knowledge of the matter.  While Venezuela was once an oil-producing powerhouse, its output has declined precipitously over the past two decades and now represents less than 1% of global supplies.  Meanwhile, worldwide oil supplies are expected to exceed demand by 3.8 million barrels a day in 2026, which would mark a record, according to the International Energy Agency.

content.title: Oil Market May Absorb Maduro Shock Amid Abundant Global Supplies
content.summary: Venezuela’s oil infrastructure wasn’t affected after a series of US attacks in Caracas and other states, according to people with knowledge of the matter.  While Venezuela was once an oil-producing powerhouse, its output has declined precipitously over the past two decades and now represents less than 1% of global supplies.  Meanwhile, worldwide oil supplies are expected to exceed demand by 3.8 million barrels a day in 2026, which would mark a record, according to the International Energy Agency.

headline: Oil Market May Absorb Maduro Shock as Global Supplies Swell
summary: Venezuela’s oil infrastructure wasn’t affected after a series of US attacks in Caracas and other states, according to people with knowledge of the matter.  While Venezuela was once an oil-producing powerhouse, its output has declined precipitously over the past two decades and now represents less than 1% of global supplies.  President Donald Trump said during a press conference on Saturday that sanctions on Venezuela’s oil industry will remain in place and US oil companies will help rebuild infrastructure and revive output.

content.title: Oil Market May Absorb Maduro Shock as Global Supplies Swell
content.summary: Venezuela’s oil infrastructure wasn’t affected after a series of US attacks in Caracas and other states, according to people with knowledge of the matter.  While Venezuela was once an oil-producing powerhouse, its output has declined precipitously over the past two decades and now represents less than 1% of global supplies.  President Donald Trump said during a press conference on Saturday that sanctions on Venezuela’s oil industry will remain in place and US oil companies will help rebuild infrastructure and revive output.

headline: Trump Says U.S. Will ‘Run’ Venezuela After Maduro Is Flown to New York
summary: The U.S. is “going to run” Venezuela, President Donald Trump said at a press conference on Saturday, hours after his administration captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife and flew them to New York as part of what Trump called a “large scale strike” against Venezuela in Caracas, the country’s capital city.  “We’re going to run the country until such time as we can do a safe, proper, and judicious transition,” Trump said at the conference as U.S. officials including Secretary of State Marco Rubio stood by.

content.title: Trump Says U.S. Will ‘Run’ Venezuela After Maduro Is Flown to New York
content.summary: The U.S. is “going to run” Venezuela, President Donald Trump said at a press conference on Saturday, hours after his administration captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife and flew them to New York as part of what Trump called a “large scale strike” against Venezuela in Caracas, the country’s capital city.  “We’re going to run the country until such time as we can do a safe, proper, and judicious transition,” Trump said at the conference as U.S. officials including Secretary of State Marco Rubio stood by.

headline: Chevron in Position on Venezuela's Oil Reserves
summary: Chevron is the only major U.S. company in Venezuela, and finds itself in prime position to deliver on President Trump’s pledge Saturday to rejuvenate the Latin American country’s oil business.  The oil giant has spent years navigating the country’s political and economic turmoil while its rivals pulled out—or were kicked out of the country by Venezuelan dictators.  Venezuela’s government says its proved oil reserves top 300 billion barrels, which, if true, would make its bounty the world’s largest, ahead of Saudi Arabia and Iran.

content.title: Chevron in Position on Venezuela's Oil Reserves

The oil giant has spent years navigating the country’s political and economic turmoil while its rivals pulled out—or were kicked out of the country by Venezuelan dictators.  Venezuela’s government says its proved oil reserves top 300 billion barrels, which, if true, would make its bounty the world’s largest, ahead of Saudi Arabia and Iran.

headline: Chevron Charts a New Path in Venezuela to Unlock Vast Oil Reserves
summary: The country says its proved oil reserves top 300 billion barrels which, if true, would make its bounty the world’s largest.

headline: The Oil Sector’s Biggest Winners and Losers From Venezuela Regime Change
summary: The capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has reopened a question the oil market has largely sidelined for years: What changes if Venezuela’s oil industry begins to normalize under U.S. influence?  In comments today, President Donald Trump says the sanctions on Venezuelan oil remain in place, but he also said that the U.S. intends to be “very involved” in Venezuela’s oil sector, which he says requires billions of dollars fix the “badly broken” oil infrastructure.  While Venezuela currently produces just 1% of global supply, the Wood Mackenzie estimate of $15–20 billion to add 500,000 barrels per day highlights the capital intensity of its extra-heavy crude.

content.title: The Oil Sector’s Biggest Winners and Losers From Venezuela Regime Change
content.summary: The capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has reopened a question the oil market has largely sidelined for years: What changes if Venezuela’s oil industry begins to normalize under U.S. influence?  In comments today, President Donald Trump says the sanctions on Venezuelan oil remain in place, but he also said that the U.S. intends to be “very involved” in Venezuela’s oil sector, which he says requires billions of dollars fix the “badly broken” oil infrastructure.  While Venezuela currently produces just 1% of global supply, the Wood Mackenzie estimate of $15–20 billion to add 500,000 barrels per day highlights the capital intensity of its extra-heavy crude.

headline: Trump Wants to Unlock Venezuela’s Oil Reserves. A Huge Challenge Awaits.
summary: The president wants to put Venezuela’s viscous crude into play. The problem is the world doesn’t have much appetite for more oil.

headline: Trump makes it clear shocking Venezuelan regime change is largely about oil: ‘They stole our oil … We’re going to make a lot of money’
summary: Trump says American oil companies will rebuild the Venezuelan industry and take a "tremendous amount of wealth out of the ground."

content.title: Trump makes it clear shocking Venezuelan regime change is largely about oil: ‘They stole our oil … We’re going to make a lot of money’
content.summary: Trump says American oil companies will rebuild the Venezuelan industry and take a "tremendous amount of wealth out of the ground."

thumbnail.caption: An oil tanker is seen anchored in Lake Maracaibo after loading crude oil at the Bajo Grande Refinery port.

headline: Why is Donald Trump so interested in Venezuela's oil?
summary: Donald Trump has said the US will "run" Venezuela until a transition can take place - and tap its vast oil reserves to sell to other nations.  Speaking to reporters hours after Nicolas Maduro and his wife were captured, Mr Trump declared that "very large" American oil firms would spend billions of dollars to fix "badly broken infrastructure" in the South American country.  Venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves of any country in the world - and the president has claimed US occupation "won't cost a penny" as the country will be reimbursed from "money coming out of the ground".

content.title: Why is Donald Trump so interested in Venezuela's oil?
content.summary: Donald Trump has said the US will "run" Venezuela until a transition can take place - and tap its vast oil reserves to sell to other nations.  Speaking to reporters hours after Nicolas Maduro and his wife were captured, Mr Trump declared that "very large" American oil firms would spend billions of dollars to fix "badly broken infrastructure" in the South American country.  Venezuela has the largest proven oil reserves of any country in the world - and the president has claimed US occupation "won't cost a penny" as the country will be reimbursed from "money coming out of the ground".

headline: U.S. will look to tap Venezuelan oil reserves, Trump says
